images.caption: Figure 1:a) Overview of the INP-X pipeline. The unmasked regions of the generated output are replaced with the corresponding regions from the original image, preserving original content while retaining the synthesized masked area. b) The difference between Original-Inpainted and Original-Ours. c) INP: Inpainting Pipeline.
Original Image
Original Image
Standard Inpainting

Figure 3:Verification of VAE-induced artifacts. Columns from left to right: (1) Original Image, (2) Mask, (3) Inpainted Result, (4) High-Frequency Filters of the Original Image, (5) VAE Reconstruction Artifacts (decoding encoded original), (6) Difference Map (Inpainted - Original). Note the strong structural correlation between the VAE artifacts and the final inpainting difference, confirming the VAE as the primary source of global noise.
Figure 4:Scatter plots showing strong correlations between VAE reconstruction loss and inpainting artifacts.
(a)Accuracy vs Mask Size (INP)
(a)Accuracy vs Mask Size (INP)
(b)Accuracy vs Mask Size (INP-X)
Figure 6:Sequence of correlation matrices showing the relationships between different error metrics across datasets.
Figure 7:Histograms of pixel-level correlations.
Figure 7:Histograms of pixel-level correlations.
Figure 8:Boxplots of pixel-level correlations.
Figure 9:Detailed accuracy breakdown by sub-folder for each dataset.
Figure 10:Accuracy of detectors on Real Images across different datasets.

Figure 11:Localization examples showing detector attention via GradCAM. (a) Mask indicates the inpainted region. (b) Standard inpainting triggers global attention across the image. (c) Our Inpainting Exchange method better localizes attention to the actual edited region.

Figure 12:Additional Comparison of standard inpainting versus Inpainting Exchange. From left to right: Original image, Mask, Standard Inpainting, Difference (Original - Inpainting), Inpainting Exchange (INP-X), and Difference (Original - INP-X). The difference maps reveal that standard inpainting introduces global artifacts across the entire image, while our method produces differences only within the masked region.

Figure 13:Frequency domain analysis comparing real images, standard inpainting, and our Inpainting Exchange method. The FFT magnitude spectra reveal the global spectral artifacts introduced by standard inpainting, which are eliminated in our approach.

Figure 14:Analysis of RePaint (VAE-less inpainting). Comparison of (1) Original Image, (2) Mask, (3) RePaint Output, and (4) Difference Map. While the unmasked region is perfectly preserved (zero difference), the method is prohibitively slow and requires dataset-specific training.

Figure 15:Even improved models like SDXL and FLUX.1 exhibit characteristic VAE reconstruction artifacts that correlate with the inpainting error. Columns from left to right: (1) Original Image, (2) Mask, (3) Inpainted Result, (4) High-Frequency Filters of the Original Image, (5) VAE Reconstruction Artifacts (decoding encoded original), (6) Difference Map (Inpainted - Original).
